page.title: 06SURROUNDING DOWNS
page.content: Throwley is on the North Downs. The height varies from 80 metres in the North to 140 metres in the South. This means stronger winds, more rain and cooler temperatures than lower down. There are three kinds of soil. On the Down tops it is clay with flints, on the valley sides it is chalky, and in the valley bottoms there is good silty soil. There is no grade 1 land,40% of grade 2, 35% of grade 3, and 5% of grade 4. The remaining 20% is woodland. The problems of the area include the steep slopes of the valleys, the hard flints that can damage machinery, and animal pests such as rabbits and pigeons. In recent years much of the grassland has been ploughed for cerial and rape crops, because of the good economic return.
